description:
Amycolatopsis xylanica is a species of actinobacteria that was first isolated from soil collected in Xylana, China. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. 

The cells of A. xylanica are typically rod-shaped and can form branched filaments. The colony morphology on agar plates is described as circular, convex, and smooth with a yellowish-white pigmentation.

Phylogenetically, A. xylanica belongs to the genus Amycolatopsis, which is part of the family Pseudonocardiaceae. Genome analysis has revealed that this species has a high G+C content, characteristic of many actinobacteria.

A. xylanica is known to be capable of degrading various polysaccharides, including xylan, and can utilize xylose as a sole carbon source. This metabolic capability suggests potential applications in the conversion of lignocellulosic biomass.

Further research is still needed to fully elucidate the ecological role, physiological properties, and potential biotechnological uses of this actinobacterial species.
